data.text: How Do You Make a Living? A Question for All Bike Travellers

General question for all the bike travellers out there...For those that cycle for months or even years...how do you make a living? I understand those that are retired but genuinely curious about others my age. I would love to do something like doing months long trips on my bike. Is it a matter of selling all assets and living minimallly...

I work and save for a couple of years then go away for months. Then return and do the same routine again. I find it‚Äôs paying bills back home that is the costly part as you can live quite cheaply while away.
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: That‚Äôs how I live. I may have around $500 a month going out total. Easy to save.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I agree, much cheaper to travel than live at home if you do it right
data.author: Ivan Gorodess

data.text: I have lived most of my adult life as a nomad. I work roughly 5 months a year as a tour leader on international tours around the globe. And then I travel the world for fun the rest of the year. I have worked with this in 40 different countries so far. Liechtenstein will be my country #41 to have worked in this year. Between my tours I go tour cycling or hiking around the parts of the world where I have just worked, or will work next. All that I need, in order to live this lifestyle is to be online for 20-30 minutes every morning and answer work related e-mails. So O am cycling with a small Macbook Air. I like the combination of staying in nice hotels and eating in nice restaurants when I work. And then when I am not working I live more simple life in small pensions. I am writing these lines from Ravello, by the Amalfi coast, where I just got back from a 10 hour hike in the mountains. My native Denmark, London and Istanbul will be my next destinations. And either my bike or my hiking boots will travel with me on all trips.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: that sounds great. Is there a way to get into it? I would love to do it, I think
data.author: Christa Calleja

data.text: fantastic!
data.author: Hannah Pierce-Carlson

data.text: I got in to it by talking to lots of people at travel fairs, trade fairs and so on . I had already travelled for a few years before I started doing it. So my argument for being hired to do this was that I had a lot of travel experience. If you would like to get in to this, then I wish you all the best and hope to see you out there one day.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: thanks
data.author: Christa Calleja

data.text: I cook at a University fraternity house and have summers off. I apply for and receive unemployment benefits without having to report a weekly ‚Äújob search‚Äù. I am ‚Äúlaid off‚Äù and returning to the same job, as opposed to being ‚Äúterminated ‚Äú.
data.author: Terence Edwards

data.text: I work as a barista/coffee roaster in a small tourist town in Florida for a few months while living minimally on a dock. When the slow season hits I leave on my bike but when it gets busy I return. Have funded 5 multi month tours doing this now. It's not glamorous but it works
data.author: Caitlin McCauley

data.text: you are an absolute star. Gutsy lady or what

data.text: thank you! ü•∞

Caitlin McCauley

data.text: Ok, that's pretty rad!

data.text: watercraft, long distance biking, freedom, adventure sounds amazing. How can I gain that life
data.author: Andy Thompson

data.text: That‚Äôs why many of us wait till we are retired
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: For long travel we always stay in tent and most of our cost is food. And where you cycling also can minimize the cost. We worked like a year in australia and spend 3 years cycling
data.author: Violet Biru

data.text: I got lucky and was able to retire young, but you can also tour very cheaply if you are OK with camping and cooking yourself. I spend around $20 a day of I camp, and less of I can wild camp. This is in South Africa, which is cheaper than Europe for example, but consider that a suggestion to find cheaper countries to tour. You can also find countries like Australia where you can work on the farms for a month and make good money, and then carry on.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Work and save.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: this is the way
data.author: Shona MacArthur

data.text: It cost us around ¬£7000 for a year per person which will give you approximately ¬£20 a day. We worked on ¬£10 a day but had a back of double for more expensive places. We camped 90% of the time. Very rarely ate out but did depend on country ie Ecuador was almost cheaper to eat out then buy in the suoer market. When you wild camp and eat very basic foods you can live on next to nothing but as with everything there comes high cost items like bike parts, repairs, clothes and beer. Just like with cycle touring you can carry huge amounts of gear or hardly anything, you can have a very cheap second hand bike or a all bells and whistles bike. The same goes for food you can live off of beans, rice and even pick from nature but the most important key is to make it fun and not a chore. Hope this helps
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text: I followed your and Sharon's blog all the way through and always wondered how you were doing after completing your journey. I'm glad to see you're still out there exploring!
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: 7000 for a year! That‚Äôs insane ü§Ø
data.author: Cameron Adam

data.text: ha ha, 'beer'
data.author: Embert Aarts

data.text: - I met a couple who were on the last leg of their RTW tour and it ended up costing them ‚Ç¨7200 a year per person. I was impressed at the figure, but they did seem to miss out on some stuff for budgeting purposes, so I figured I'd want to have close to double so that I don't have to miss out on as much.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: in some ways yes it is but when travelling through countries like Norway which are so expensive but in contrast Poland and far east countries are super cheap. I was questioned at a US border what countries I had been through. I named 40 countries which was followed by "what do you do for a living? And how can you afford to go to 40 countries?" On reflection if you travelled to 40 countries separately with insurance, flights, baggage costs, other travel costs you could average ¬£1000 per country give or take. As a couple over 2 years we spent ¬£14000 so 3500 per year per person but then travelling on my own costs increased slightly because its cheaper to cook for 2 then 1 (cost per head) and rooms for 1 aren't much cheaper then fir 2. As I've mentioned you need to allow for the unforseen. Ie tyres, rims splitting, frames snapping, warranty exchanges and needing to wait in accommodation for them to arrive and your bike being stolen all of which happened to us.
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text: hi and thank you for following us. It was an incredible journey in so many ways and long to head back out in the road. Since finishing my trip I have continued to cycle but not had the chance to do any long tours. I've renovated a house and in the midst of renovating a large farmhouse while having a little boy. Covid hasn't helped with planning trips but that fire to tour is as bright as ever. Hope all is great with you
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text: Woah, congratulations on the little one and building a home. That's awesome! You'll have to corrupt him in to cycling one day as well üòÉ And thank you, I'm doing ok right now. Lots of things in flux right now so who knows where life will take me. Hopefully somewhere with a tailwind!

Cycle touring may be a generally middle class pursuit but that‚Äôs because of people‚Äôs outlook on life, not because they get financial support from family or ‚Äúinvestment income‚Äù. Most long distance cycle tourists have to work hard, save hard and live frugally, especially on long trips.

data.text: We are currently in thr midst of cycling through Spain and Portugal (we live in portugal) and have to work every few days on the road so that we can afford to take trips like this. We are lucky to have remote jobs. But we work hard and carry our computers and tech with us

data.text: Same as most opinions...
data.author: Jak Conrad

data.text: I retired, sold my house, sold most of my stuff and put the rest in storage, and then bought a ticket for me and my bicycle to go to Amsterdam. OK, the real story is a bit more complicated than that but I ended up being house-free for six years. No regrets.

data.text: I have relatives in Europe with bikes so I don't have to worry about bringing mine. They also provide logistics and will pick me up if needed.

data.text: At the moment i just settle down somewhere while on a bike tour for a few weeks or months and do Workaway‚Äôs (unpaid but it gives you somewhere to live and free meals too). Then on my days off I‚Äôll look for odd jobs or go busking and that‚Äôs how I‚Äôll save up üôÇ

data.text: this is awesome. More of the path I can probably take in the future.

data.text: I have worked in freelance in Outdoor Education in Australia where I usually worked Feb-April/May then go overseas to a northern hemisphere summer where I cycle until end of September before flying back to Australia to working again until Christmas.
data.author: Joel Emonson

data.text: what‚Äôs outdoor education?
data.author: Nelson Incog Nito

data.text: taking school students into the outdoors on various camps, where they can do a variety of activities from hiking to canoeing and sometimes cycling.
data.author: Joel Emonson

data.text: is this a formal education that Australian government introduced to their education system? Am just curious.
data.author: Anthony Ramalla

data.text: it's very common in private schools and many government schools also do this. For most students it's 5 days away from school a year but other schools and students for longer. My current full time role is with a school that sends 50 year 9 students away for 5 weeks at a time
data.author: Joel Emonson

data.text: I know a couple from Spain who do the same as you.
data.author: Omare War

data.author: Nelson Incog Nito

data.text: We worked hard for a long time. We travel to countries that are cheaper to live in than where we live eg, Thailand, South America, Mexico. We rented our house out and lived off that for 18 months. Savings paid my mortgage while away. We‚Äôre about to do another trip. Again worked hard and saved. We will live off the rent of our house. Where we live it is easy to rent our house out. I think it‚Äôs about priorities and what you spend your money on.
data.author: Sean Liz

data.text: wait so you make money after mortgage payments and agency fees from renting?! Thats amazing, I‚Äôve only heard of folk pretty much breaking even when renting out a mortgaged property.

data.author: Ricky Bushell

data.text: I've been cycling around the world (not one continuous line, though) for some 11 years now, about 48.000 km, some 38 countries. Sometimes I stay in one place 3 weeks or even 3 months. Just got back to my "base" in Berlin after 5.5 months in Mexico, where I only did some 2.600 km. I'm always looking for a new client or two. I translate (FR/EN/ES/JP/DE into EN or ES) and I teach Spanish and English via Skype. So my daily routine might be: cycling from wherever I camped for a couple of hours (maybe 3-4 hours?) and then stop at some cafe or restaurant along the road, work online or muck around, or maybe cycle longer and then take a long break under some shade in a park (maybe use my own internet/sim card connection), dry out my gear, take a nap, etc, and in the late afternoon/evening bike another 2-3 hour and find the next camping spot. Recently, though, because of Covid, my business/work has gone down, by 75%!!! So fortunately I am subsisting on the social security benefits (one advantage of growing old, LOL) which almost make up my meager budget. As a cycling nomad you normally don't have great needs, and I've always been a minimalist anyway. So all these years my monthly budget has been between 360 and more recently 450 EUR/month. So basically I can get by on 12-14 EUR per day. And that actually includes the occasional flight, bikes, repairs, clothing (ha ha, maybe 50 EUR a year!), electronics, food and accommodation. 2021 was Portugal, Spain (by bus), France, Germany, Poland and Mexico. 2020 might be Mexico, Germany, Spain, Morocco (or Japan). Now I'm looking to find/create a nomad base for myself and maybe with others (like a cooperative) on the coast between Conil and Tarifa (Cadiz, Spain). Something that 5-6 fellow nomads will take care of while the other 5-6 nomads are away. Anyone interested?
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Thank you all for sharing. Really cool to get all these honest responses. Definitely admire many of you all for taking control of life as such. üëèüèΩ
data.author: Jonathan Goldsworthy

data.text: Piss off the other half. .get busted and lose it all as a desdbeat drunk and then you can start over. ..
data.author: Bob Rees

data.text: i work Subway, hospitality, or retail in towns and ski resorts for the winters. i spend all my money getting out of debt from the last tour, and upgrading gear for the next. it really doesn't cost a lot of money. never been one for a career, jobs suit me just five
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: Once I took a deferred leave to be able to go on a long tour. It involved a 10 % pay reduction over 5 years, resulting in 6 months off work with a paycheque still coming in.
data.author: Wayne Wood

data.text: - Great strategy. Congrats
data.author: Fred Schlomka

data.text: I was laid off, so no paycheck to save. My husband was able to take an unpaid leave. We sold the car, rented the house, I taught a class on line, we went into debt, lived without a car for several years after we got back. I wrote a book about the trip and went into even more debt writing. Oh, and over 143 households put us up, and most fed us too. We were on the road 420 days.
data.author: Anne Winkler-Morey

data.text: Wild camp and eat cheap grocery food and the budget is low
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: A friend of mine owned a small house (she was not rich or middle class) she would rent it out for a year or more while she travelled. Then when she got back to UK she had a home base. She would work for a bit if she could to top up here finances, and live rent free. Most of her travel costs were covered by the rent.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I hope to do that
data.author: Karen Vin

data.text: Man y‚Äôall gettin me too excited. I get a disability of $1200 a month for the rest of my life and in no way does it affect me riding. Much more talk like this and I‚Äôll quit my job forgoing a retirement pension
data.author: Robert Scott

data.text: do it. One thing I can guarantee is you won't regret it and will change your life forever
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text: I taught English all over Asia for years. Short year and some change contracts, just enough time to learn the language, study history, places, and plot routes and cycle all over my local spot in all my free time. Travelled as a solo female cyclist in China. Met my husband and kept going, Taiwan, China to Malaysia! üö¥ Now we have two amazing kids and dog and we worldschool! Raising them free, and knowing the real ‚Äúreal world.‚Äù Husband is a nurse. Never stop traveling if it‚Äôs what lights you up, despite money and family circumstances, you can find a way.
data.author: Hannah Pierce-Carlson

data.text: you live my dream. Great to know someone does it. üëèüèªüëèüèªüëèüèª
data.author: Anita Long

data.text: it‚Äôs üíØ for you. You can see it and gather a bit of evidence that others do this too, to bolster your own belief in the possibilities, you‚Äôre off to the races!
data.author: Hannah Pierce-Carlson

data.text: Im sharing this! Mebbe itll convince her to come with me‚Ä¶.
data.author: Philip Iau

data.text: For my year long trip I set a budget, saved up and rented out my apartment. Small things like cooking at home instead of takeaway and not going out drinking will help you achieve your saving goal. Now I have an online job and I will do some test runs to see if I can enjoy bike travel while maintaining my job. All I need is my laptop and phone with data and a dry spot to sit for a few hours every day.
data.author: Vera Van De Nieuwenhof

data.text: I have been a digital nomad since the late 1980's when black & white laptops and 'bag phones' were the latest thing in mobile communication. It got easier from there. As an early adopter of e-commerce I found it efficient to work on the road. My latest enterprise has staff in three countries, no front office, and all our infrastructure in the cloud. Even in developing countries there is decent 3G or 4G mobile networks along the main roads almost everywhere. Even when on months-long cycling adventures, I'm up at 5am and spend a few hours working before hitting the road. Then another hour or two of work later in the day. This has worked from Ethiopia to Nebraska, and Mexico to the Kingdom of Jordan. Happy cycling . . . .
data.author: Fred Schlomka

data.text: Mostly men here, though. Does it have to do with "roughing it"?
data.author: Ignacio Duran
Dimitris Papamastorakis

data.text: I'm a travel nurse. I work my butt of, live like a pauper, and take looooong breaks in between contracts.
data.author: Jaelanne Sade

data.text: An Anglo/French couple I know cashed out their assets (sold an apartment in London) and stopped awhile somewhere along the way and taught their respective languages to replenish their funds and then continued on their way. They rode from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego on their first trip and across Asia and back (plus NZ & Australia) on the second.

data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: On sabbatical. Saved for 2 years. Don't need to work for a year while away. Will do the same again in a few years
data.author: Tristan James

data.text: Hi , I am self-employed. I have an online business where I can work from anywhere. All I need is a basic internet connection. And the best part is that I can fully automate it so that eventually it works for me, even when I'm cycling or sleeping at night. I'm not quite there yet, but I'm in the right direction. Basically it's affiliate marketing: I sell other people's products and make a commission on the sales. It allows me to work at my own pace, without having to manage the demands of clients or a boss. It's really great and I've been traveling for 9 months, working from everywhere on my way. If you want, I can give you access to a free training that explains in detail how it works. I think you might be interested in it at this point in your research. Just let me know in the comments and I'll send it to you. I wish you good luck in your endeavors. It's really great to be able to just live on your bike!
data.author: Patrice Audet

data.text: Thank you . Seems like an awesome gig. In the future I might take you up on the offer. If I were to move forward, it would be in years to come, currently have a young family...getting ideas on how I could make something like this work in the future.
data.author: Jonathan Goldsworthy

data.text: The best thing is: you can start now, and have your structure ready when the kids are a bit older. If this is something important for you (I mean, your freedom), don't push it forever forward. The "right" timing may never come...
data.author: Patrice Audet

data.text: Work your ass off and save up before you play.

data.text: always better to have too much money than not enough. While you can do it for much cheaper, I found I skipped things of interest, which I regret now
